mdRecord.dcterms:description: Grosvenor Atterbury renowned architect was given the commission to design the Forest Hills Gardens. The neighborhood was planned on the model of the garden communities of England. The Forest Hills Gardens were the first and are the oldest of the planned communities. The Gardens are credited as the leading American contribution to the Garden Cities movement and one of the most recognized. This new science of city planning allowed commuters to have country living in the city. This was their alternative to cramped New York City flats. Atterbury designed elegant, substantial Tudor and Colonial style homes. Throughout the Gardens you will see towers, spires, fancy brickwork, Tudor exposed half timbers and red tile clay roofs. Frederick Law Olmstead, Jr. son of the landscape architect of New York City’s central park was the landscape architect for the Forest Hills Gardens project. He planned curving streets lined with stately trees, closes, two small parks, Flag Pole Green, and Station Square. -- http://www.foresthillschamber.org/en/history/ [work]
